#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Diving Aliwal Shoal
#Text=This article is intended to provide the already qualified Scuba diver with information which will help to plan dives in the waters of Aliwal Shoal , whether as a local resident or a visitor .
#Text=Information is provided without prejudice , and is not guaranteed accurate or complete .
#Text=Use it at your own risk .
#Text=Detailed information on individual dive sites is provided in the sub-articles linked from the Dive sites section .
#Text=The information in the site descriptions ranges from superficial to highly detailed , depending on what is known about the site .
#Text=In some instances a dive site sub-article will include several sites which are in close proximity , as much of the information will be common to them all .
#Text=In other cases , usually involving wreck sites , two closely adjacent sites will each have their own sub-article .
#Text=Understand
#Text=During 1849 , after a ship , the Aliwal , nearly collided with an uncharted reef , its captain reported the position of this reef that later became known as the Aliwal Shoal .
#Text=It is located about 60 km south of Durban in South Africa .
#Text=The closest towns are Umkomaas and Scottburgh , both of which offer extensive tourist facilities , also for scuba divers .
#Text=General Topography
#Text=The Aliwal Shoal is a fossilised sand dune lying roughly parallel to the coast , about 5 km from the shore .
#Text=It comprises a narrow northern part ( the crown , some 250 m wide , becoming about 800 m wide and finally with a wider landward ridge to the south , greater than 2 km in width .
#Text=The crown varies in depth from about 6 m ( around the Northern Pinnacles ) to around 30 m on the seaward side .
#Text=The mean depth of the crown area is 12.5 m. The southern wider area includes several protrusions that reach from a depth of some 30 m to around 15 m ( e. g. Howard 's Castle , Landers Reef ) .

#Text=In the crown area , many dive sites , e.g. Raggie Cave and Chunnel have a large amount of uneven topography with small caves , ledges and swimthroughs rich in sea life , both fish-wise as well as in invertebrates , e.g. octopus .
#Text=Climate , Weather and Sea conditions
#Text=The Aliwal Shoal has a subtropical climate witch mean monthly air temperatures ranging from 17.0°C ( Jul ) to 23.9°C ( Feb ) .
#Text=The sea temperatures tend to be somewhat warmer , due to the warm , tropical , southward-flowing Mozambique sea current , resulting in a balmy 21-26°C throughout the year .
#Text=Mean monthly weather statistics at or near the Aliwal Shoal :

#Text=The period May to July has the least wind ( 18 to 19 days per month less than 20 km/h , i.e. small waves with breaking crests and fairly frequent whitecaps ) , while September to November is more windy ( 10-11 days less than 20 km/h ) .

#Text=Depending on sea current conditions , underwater visibility is sometimes strongly affected by effluent from the Sappi-SAICCOR paper mill at Umkomaas , released through a pipe that runs some 6 km into the sea just north of the shoal , venting along a considerable length of the pipe .
#Text=The shoal often has strong currents that can be from the north or from the south .
#Text=This makes for fantastic drift diving .
#Text=Marine Life
#Text=The Aliwal Shoal is a fossilised dune upon which coral and other sessile animals have established .
#Text=It is therefore not a true coral reef comprising the calcareous remains of dead corals upon which other corals grow .
#Text=It is a coral site surprisingly far from the equator , made possible by the warm southwards-flowing Mozambique current .
#Text=Therefore it contains many of the subtropical and tropical species found further north .
#Text=However , the hard corals are relatively rare compared to those on tropical reefs and soft corals are much more common .
#Text=The same applies to the tropical fish encountered on the shoal : they are relative more sparse than on tropical reefs .

#Text=However , a surprising variety of tropical fish are still found on the shoal , including many species of surgeonfish , goldies , rockcod , triggerfish , cardinals , scorpionfish , lionfish and representatives of most other tropical fish genera .
#Text=The wreck of the MV Produce houses the endemic Harlequin goldie Pseudanthias connelli .
#Text=Aliwal shoal is well known for the ragged-tooth sharks
#Text=Carcharias taurus mostly encountered during winter .
#Text=They pup in the cold water of the Cape during summer .
#Text=During May to August they migrate up the east coast of southern Africa and mate in the vicinity of the Durban on the KwaZulu-Natal coast , including the Aliwal Shoal .
#Text=After mating they spend a few months along the subtropical coast of Mozambique before returning to the Cape in the early summer .
#Text=They prefer to rest in holes , caves or depressions large enough to contain sharks .
#Text=They frequently swim slowly in a semi-sleep condition and can bump against divers .
#Text=The shoal commonly hosts blacktip reef sharks Carcharhinus melanopterus , bull sharks Carcharhinus leucas and tiger sharks Galeocerdo cuvier , the latter often found at deeper depths .
#Text=Blacktip reef sharks are the most commonly encountered animals during baited dives .

#Text=The shoal has large numbers of invertebrate species such as sponges , coral ( mostly soft corals ) , molluscs such as octopus , cowries and nudibranchs , crustaceans such as shrimps and lobsters , as well as sea anemones .
#Text=The Marine Ecology
#Text=At more than 30 degrees south , the Aliwal Shoal lies at the extreme latitude at which tropical corals have been observed worldwide .
#Text=The biodiversity on the shoal is shaped mainly by the amount of light that penetrates the sea water and by the physical wave action .
#Text=The shallow , northern part of the shoal with depth 6-10 m , is dominated by hard corals and sponges .

#Text=Since hard corals are generally dependent on plant cells within the coral body ( zooxanthellae ) , they are critically dependent on light for the photosynthetic products produced by the zooxanthellae .
#Text=The most common hard coral species at Aliwal Shoal are the knob-horned and smooth-horned corals ( Pocillopora sp . and Stylophora pistillata , repectively ) .
#Text=The hard corals define a distinct community of animals along the top of the crown , found at dive sites such as the Northern Pinnacles and Pinnacle Ridge .
#Text=The encrusting sponge Subites kelleri is also common in this area .
#Text=The corals and sponges on these parts of the reef are physically robust and can withstand the wave action in shallow water .
#Text=A second distinct community on the shoal is characterised by specific soft corals , e.g. the Dead Man 's Fingers ( Eleutherobia aurea ) .
#Text=These corals do not have zooxanthellae , are mostly dependent on water movement for feeding on small free-floating organisms , and cannot survive where the wave action is very strong .
#Text=This community also has many sea worms ( Polychaeta ) and is found along the seaward as well as landward edges of the shoal at dive sites such as Raggie Sands , Blowhole and Inside Edge .
#Text=The third community is poor in distinctive corals an sponges , situated at greater depths , especially towards the southern end of the crown .
#Text=However it still contains a large array of sea animals and it is easy to locate colourful nudibranchs .
#Text=This area has a large abundance of algae and is found at dive sites such as North Wall and Burn Rock .
